results.title: American Ballet Theatre in San Francisco
results.creator_credit: Robin Scott, National Video Corporation and Brian Large
results.brief_description: This is a companion piece to “American Ballet Theatre at the Met” and features five short ballets including two pas de deaux performed by the American Ballet Theater at the War Memorial Opera House, San Francisco with the San Francisco Opera Orchestra on 1st March 1985. Artistic director: Mikhail Baryshnikov. Airs: Music by George Frideric Handel, choreography by Paul Taylor, conducted by Paul Connelly and featuring dancers Peter Fonseca, Johan Renvall, Lisa Rinehart. Jardin aux lilas (Lilac garden): Music by Ernest Chausson, choreography by Antony Tudor, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Leslie Browne, Martine Van Hamel, Robert La Fosse, Michael Owen. The Black swan from Swan Lake (Act III): Pas de deaux. Music by Piotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, choreography by Marius Petipa, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Cynthia Gregory, Fernando Bujones. Romeo and Juliet - Balcony pas de deux (Act I): Music by Sergei Prokofiev, choreography by Kenneth MacMillan, conducted by Alan Barker and featuring dancers Natalia Makarova, Kevin McKenzie. Great galloping Gottschalk: Music by Louis Moreau Gottschalk, choreography by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, conducted by Paul Connelly and featuring dancers Susan Jaffe, Robert La Fosse.

results.title: America: from Hitler to M-X
results.creator_credit: Parallel Films, Fourth Wall Repertory, Albee Gordon, Ralph Klein, Saul Newton and Joan Harvey
results.brief_description: A striking film statement about the military aims of the United States today; its longstanding first strike policy, and the escalating threat of worldwide annihilation. Here is an expose of America’s top level corporate and banking links with fascism for over sixty years. The film indicts the United States as aggressor in today’s international move to war

results.title: America. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
D.W. Griffith’s epic historical spectacle of the American Revolution, shot on the actual locations, and staged with almost documentary realism. The cast is headed by Neil Hamilton, Lionel Barrymore, Carol Dempster and Louis Wolhiem. This is an edited version of the original film which was made in 1909.

results.title: America wide
results.brief_description: This multi-media presentation contains thousands of images of America (taken across all 50 states) as photographed by Australian Ken Duncan. The stunning panoramic images convey the diversity of the landscape and the beauty of nature. The images are accompanied by music composed by Andy Sorenson, with eleven separate tracks. Also includes the piece Song for America by Kathy Johnston.

Also includes the piece Song for America by Kathy Johnston.

results.title: America on the edge of abundance
results.brief_description: Traces America’s snowballing history as an affluent society and looks at the dilemma which abundance brings. A land of abounding factory production and consumption, where success is measured by material standards. America underwent a revolution from an agricultural to an manufacturing society. Now a second revolution looms, to an automated society. What will this mean to the nation, and how individuals will accept a society in which a minority of people can manage the nation’s work, is discussed.

results.title: America in Vietnam
results.creator_credit: Information Television Productions, Cinequity Funding, Ian Macleod, Ron Kelly, Paul Lang and Don North
results.brief_description: A preview of the series “Vietnam: the ten thousand day war”, covering America’s shifting motivations and priorities during three decades of the Vietnam conflict. The conflict became America’s longest, costliest, and most mysterious war and involved five presidencies. Written by Pulitzer Prize winner, Peter Arnett and narrated by Richard Basehart.

results.title: America abroad
results.creator_credit: Peter Hunt, Associated-Rediffusion, Intertel and Michael Ingrams
results.brief_description: Approximately 2,000,000 United States citizens live and work abroad, in some 70 nations which benefit from American aid. Four of these countries and some of these United States citizens are in Cambodia, Vietnam, Pakistan and Ghana.

results.title: America's traffic problem
results.brief_description: Presents the national traffic problem created by an automotive age, and shows some of the solutions which have been put into effect to alleviate the situation. Far-sighted educators know that a partial solution to the traffic dilemma is the training of young people in good driving techniques. No other credits available.

results.title: America
results.creator_credit: Chris Granlund, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Changing stages”.
Third episode in the six-part series “Changing stages”, written and presented by Richard Eyre, about the history of theatre in the 20th century. Whilst Britain was staging its satirical and often light-hearted societal plays in the decades leading up to the 50s, American theatre had grown, changed and developed its own unique style mirroring the mood and social changes of the time. In this episode, Richard Eyre takes us on that historical journey from Provincetown in 1916 where New York writers, poets, playwrights and political activists from Greenwich Village gathered together in small beach shacks exchanging ideas, philosophising, and creating serious political and social works, through to Broadway and New Orleans and the golden age of musicals, vaudevilles, burlesque and finally to Hollywood and the 1950s. Explores the effect and influence on American theatre and American playwrights through the Great Depression, two world wars, McCarthyism, the elusive “American dream” and the collision of race and cultures, and features biographical essays on Eugene O’Neil, Clifford Odets, Arthur Miller, Tennessee Williams and Lorraine Hansberry. Through film excerpts and stills, including “The Iceman cometh” and “A Long day’s journey into night” (O’Neil); “Waiting for Lefty” and “Awake and sing” (Odets); “Death of a salesman” and “The Crucible” (Miller); “A Streetcar named desire” and “The Glass menagerie” (Williams); “A Raisin in the sun” (Hansberry) Eyre demonstrates the contribution and impact each of these playwrights made on the American psyche. Eyre also discusses the birth of the American musical, composer Richard Rodgers and lyricists Lorenz Hart and Oscar Hammerstein and the important place this art form has in American culture. Includes interviews with Arthur Miller, Jason Robards, Arthur Laurents, Luise Rainer, Clifford Odets, Hal Prince, Kim Hunter, Tennessee Williams and others. Contains some b&w footage. For more information see www.pbs.org/wnet/changingstages.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Granlund, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC

results.title: America
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts and Hernan Bornas
results.brief_description: Phoebe, Spencer, Felix and Mike have reached a point in their lives where they can no longer call Australia home. Is this due to the recurring statement that Australia is the little brother of America, or the fact that they work at “All American Videos, where too much is never enough”? It is in the videostore, a direct representation of American popular culture, that they devise a plan to rob a bank. They use their favourite films as source material to create the perfect crime.
